title: Weak productivity is threatening Canada’s post-pandemic wage growth
summary: Canadian wage growth has been high but not sufficient to keep pace with inflation, especially considering the tight labor market earlier in the pandemic recovery. Real wages fell by 1% in 2021 and 2.5% in 2022, with only a slight recovery in 2023. Canada's productivity growth is lagging, ranking 5th among G7 countries since 2019, with output per hour worked falling below 2019 levels. This underperformance is increasing unit labor costs and reducing competitiveness relative to the U.S. The labor market is softening, with unemployment rising and job openings decreasing, which may slow wage growth further. Long-term wage increases depend on productivity growth, which is hindered by low business investment and ineffective utilization of immigrant skills. Without improvements in productivity, living standards may stagnate.

'In Manitoba, the five-year retention rate fell by 11.0 percentage points, from 75.1% among immigrants admitted in 2012 to 64.1% for those admitted in 2016.' 'In the Atlantic region, both New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island experienced an uptick in the five-year retention rate for immigrants who were admitted in 2016.' 'For the 2016 admission cohort, 91.7% of immigrants sponsored by family and 86.4% of refugees filed taxes in their intended destination province or territory five years after their admission.' 'The five-year retention rate of economic immigrants admitted from 2012 to 2016 trended downward; it dropped 4.2 percentage points, from 82.1% for the 2012 cohort to 77.9% for that of 2016.' 'Among immigrants admitted as caregivers in 2016, 94.9% still filed taxes in their intended destination province or territory five years later, while this was the case for 88.1% of immigrants from the CEC.' 'The one-year retention rate for Alberta fell by 2.3 percentage points from the 2016 admission cohort (88.0%) to that of 2020 (85.7%).' 'In Newfoundland and Labrador, the one-year retention rate grew by 11.4 percentage points, from 55.0% for the 2016 admission cohort to 66.4% for that of 2020.' 'Overall, the one-year retention rate for skilled immigrants in the Atlantic provinces for the 2020 admission cohort was higher than the rate prior to the launch of the AIPP.' 'Nova Scotia experienced the highest increase to the retention rate of skilled immigrants (+42.4 percentage points), up from 21.5% for the 2016 cohort to 63.9% for that of 2020.' 'Newfoundland and Labrador's one-year retention rate increased by 18.7 percentage points, from 31.3% for skilled immigrants admitted in 2016 to 50.0% for those admitted in 2020.' 'With the exception of Prince Edward Island, all of the Atlantic provinces experienced slight declines in retaining skilled immigrants admitted in 2020 compared with the 2019 admission cohort.'

title: Study: The school closest to home: Proximity of French-language elementary schools and enrolment in the Maritime provinces
summary: In the Maritime provinces in 2021, 72% of elementary school-aged children eligible for French instruction attended French-language schools, with higher rates among those with a French-speaking parent (92%) and those living closer to a French-language school (89%). Three-quarters lived within 10 km of a French-language school, and 51% lived closer to a French-language school than an English-language one. Enrolment in French-language schools was 89% when the nearest school was French but dropped to 56% when the nearest was English. Parental language at home was the strongest factor influencing enrolment, with 92% attendance for children with at least one French-speaking parent.
